urn:contentItem:5W4N-BH51-DY1J-T18G-00000-00White House Pushes To Report 'Political Bias' By Social Media Companies2019-05-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:46:07ZLexisNexisAll Things Considered09:00 PM ESTAarti ShahaniJillian YorkEmmanuel MacRonKate KlonickWhite House Pushes To Report 'Political Bias' By Social Media Companies

AUDIE CORNISH: President Trump has a new website up, and it's asking Americans to report when a big tech company censors them. It's the latest move in his campaign against big tech, which he's accused of anti-conservative bias. And compared to other global leaders, he's taking a distinctly adversarial, outsider approach. NPR's Aarti Shahani reports.

AARTI SHAHANI: The world over, people are worried that America's social media giants have too much power. Free speech die-hard Jillian York shares that concern. She goes online to check out a survey the White House put up this week.

JILLIAN YORK: So this tool says that social media platforms should advance freedom of speech. I definitely agree with that.

AARTI SHAHANI: York is with the Electronic Frontier Foundation, which advocates for Internet civil liberties. Years ago, she created a similar survey. Trump's asks about immigration status. You must say you're a U.S. citizen or a permanent resident to proceed. It asks which companies have taken action against the respondent.

JILLIAN YORK: Oh, so this is interesting. It's focused only on four platforms.

AARTI SHAHANI: Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and YouTube; hers did, too. Also like hers, Trump's asks for screenshots of what notification or pop-up the tech platform sent when they took censorship action. Though one glaring difference between hers and the president's - his final question to verify you are not a robot.

JILLIAN YORK: The Declaration of Independence was signed in what year?

AARTI SHAHANI: That is quite the verification question. Does she know her American history?

JILLIAN YORK: Well, you know, I think I do. It's - I put in 1776.

AARTI SHAHANI: York and others say it's hard to know if the White House site is for real or farcical. It has some basic coding errors. It could be designed for data collection or a ploy to collect voter contacts, they say. Either way, the Trump move to protest and shame the social media giant stands in stark contrast to the approach by another head of state, French President Emmanuel Macron.

(SOUNDBITE OF PRESS CONFERENCE)

EMMANUEL MACRON: (Through interpreter) A person who had access online to content of a racist nature.

AARTI SHAHANI: Macron, with an English voice-over, speaking at a press conference on Wednesday.

(SOUNDBITE OF PRESS CONFERENCE)

EMMANUEL MACRON: (Through interpreter) We have to progress in that area to achieve smart regulation.

AARTI SHAHANI: Trump launched his site three weeks after he sat down one-on-one with Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey, a couple weeks after Facebook banned far-right leaders like Alex Jones, and the same day other heads of state gathered in Paris to commemorate the massacre of Muslims in Christchurch, New Zealand, which was livestreamed on Facebook.

Macron has been working an insider-outsider strategy. France is developing new laws to combat cyber hate. This week he helped spearhead a gathering where governments and big tech signed a pledge to work together. He also brokered an exclusive deal with Facebook to give French regulators unprecedented insider access to the company to see how censorship decisions are made.

(SOUNDBITE OF PRESS CONFERENCE)

EMMANUEL MACRON: (Through interpreter) We must ensure that the platforms withdraw the content and enable us to identify who is disseminating the hate speech and the negative ideas.

AARTI SHAHANI: Kate Klonick, a law professor at St. John's University, says Macron and Trump have a lot in common - they both see big tech as a powerful force, they are both threatened by that power, but only one truly gets this fact.

KATE KLONICK: You can't think of these platforms as representing any one particular nation. They're transnational platforms; they represent a global audience.

AARTI SHAHANI: White House spokesman Judd Deere says the administration created the online forum because they want to hear from all Americans, regardless of their political leanings.

Aarti Shahani, NPR News.

urn:contentItem:7W77-4K70-Y8Y1-715N-00000-00White House Puts Ceiling on Government Salaries2009-01-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:46:07ZLexisNexisCAVUTO6:00 PM ESTJohn Robinson, Jonathan Hoenig, Howard Rosencrans, Tracy Byrnes, John Tabacco, Paul O'Neill, Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., Bob Olstein, Paul FlahertyNEWSFinancial012101cb.223White House Puts Ceiling on Government SalariesNeil Cavuto

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM GEITHNER, TREASURY SECRETARY NOMINEE: These were careless mistakes. They were avoidable mistakes but they were unintentional.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN HOST: (Inaudible), Tim but fear not, you are in, Tim. Tim Geithner survives the hearing about his taxes but not enough about how he plans to spend our taxes. Tonight the man who had the job Tim wants on the screw ups should make sure he does not repeat if he wants to keep that job. Then Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. seeing red over those who question all the green going green. And they say life is a parade but does that mean we have to do what the president does and stick out through the whole darn thing? We are ready to march, now.

CAVUTO: Tim Geithner gets a grilling on the taxes he didn't pay but not nearly so much on his role in failed financial rescue in which he - well all of us continue to pay. Welcome, I am Neil Cavuto. And here's the deal. Tim Geithner will be Treasury Secretary of the United States not because charges of sloppy bookkeeping aren't serious but because this financial crisis is even more serious. Yet at his Senate confirmation hearing today Mr. Geithner got more of a pummeling on his books than how he has helped handle the nation's books. He wasn't in charge of those books, mind you, but the very least he was a co-author, a co-signee if you will.

Our financial loans didn't loan and didn't rescue at bailouts that they themselves had to be bailed out. I'd like to hear more on how we botch those numbers than buttoning(ph) his own numbers. Some senators would carp about TARP but you asked Mr. Geithner how he would avoid another lark with TARP. And all because fear grips us and gosh Tim knows this stuff. He is smart. He is seasoned and he is ready just like Robert McMamara who led us into Vietnam and couldn't get us out. And Donald Rumsfeld who led us into Iraq without a plant o get us out.

So I'm trying to figure out this obsession with brainiacs. Take nothing away from how smart they are but how dumb maybe we are, too intimidated to think, maybe they aren't so smart especially when we can all clearly see the fall out of the financial rescue and assess for what it's been - dumb so far.

My next guest was asking these very question on TARP before it became a trap. In fact, George Bush's first Treasury Secretary had very serious questions and reservations about the rescue concocted by George Bush's last Treasury Secretary. Paul O'Neill joins me now. Well, good to have you.

PAUL O'NEILL, FMR. TREASURY SECRETARY: Thank you.

CAVUTO: First on Geithner, should he get it?

O'NEILL: He's going to get in.

CAVUTO: Should he?

O'NEILL: I think on balance, yes.

CAVUTO: Normally these issues - forgetting to pay your taxes and all would doom any other nominee in any other time or at least drag it out but not now because of the crisis, I guess. Should they?

O'NEILL: You know, I think as I understand the circumstances is there is to pay at some of thousands of dollars of taxes. I think as he said it is unfortunate and he wishes he had avoided but on balance I think he had to go ahead and get the job.

CAVUTO: OK. Now, your argument has always been it's the big picture and I will hit the tax saying one more time with you. Part of the big picture is knowing what you run. And part of what you run is the IRS and the folks who make the tax rules.

You don't know all the rules, you know, I don't think even they do. But it still maybe they don't but still if they send a message that he does not.

O'NEILL: Well, I don't know. Here is a question for you. There are 10,000 pages in the tax code, do you think there's any human being that understand the whole tax code? I don't. In the time I was secretary -

CAVUTO: The tax is -

O'NEILL: Well, Neil, I will give you an example. Do you know, that if you have an employee yourself, who cleans your house and it's against the law for you to give them a gift. Did you know, that? You probably thought you could give $10,000 a year to anyone without reporting it to the gift tax threshold. If not true, if you give your housekeeper a Christmas gift even if it's in goods, but particularly if it's in cash, say $10,000, you have to report it as wages paid and paid the withholding taxes on it.

(CROSSTALK)

O'NEILL: I'm giving you a specific thing. I'm telling you there are 10,000 pages.

CAVUTO: Not a big deal, move on, is what you are saying?

I would be ripped more for the handling of his role in the TARP funds that you are very critical about early on because what you saw what happened indeed has happened. So now we're going to release the other hundred 350 billion, the House is improving all these conditions, with strict provisos but they're going to screw up again.

O'NEILL: You know, when I was here with you before I told you that I thought that it was a very big mistake for the federal government to assume preferred equity positions in financial institutions. Because I greatly fear the conversation that we heard yesterday about the Royal Bank of Scotland being nationalized by the U.K. government and with the -

CAVUTO: That is a preview of coming attractions -

O'NEILL: With the flow through into the conversation here in the U.S that the federal government would have to nationalize the bank which is the worst possible idea.

CAVUTO: Well, let me ask you, a couple of months - when did I have you last time? I'm just trying to remember this because we were racing at the time with all rescues going on and at that time when they nixed the Lehman Brothers rescue. Here's what you had to say about that. Let's get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: What if something happens with Lehman? What if something happens with Lehman? You think -

O'NEILL: I'd let them go.

CAVUTO: Really?

O'NEILL: Yes. Because I think the rest of the system is sufficiently well insulated if Lehman goes down it is a consequence for the shareholders, employer and leadership but that is OK with me.

CAVUTO: You draw the line here.

O'NEILL: Yes, I think you draw the line here.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CAVUTO: Now all the Monday morning quarterback are all saying you should not have done that, not you, but Lehman should have been rescued.

O'NEILL: You know, I haven't changed my mind. If you listen carefully with what I said we should let the shareholders go to zero.

CAVUTO: Right.

O'NEILL: I didn't intend by that that we should throw the whole financial system into chaos and I think -

CAVUTO: That's what happens this Monday morning, they were saying because that is what we did. We let them go not appreciating the fact that it would let the financial system go.

O'NEILL: Yes. I think we need to be concerned. We need to worry. We need to intervene in a way that the financial system doesn't collapse because of absolute uncertainty about the counter party relationships and all of that. But it seems perfectly appropriate to me for people who are running private enterprises to if they do things that are substantially bad for them to be wiped out.

CAVUTO: We're going quite the opposite way now, right. I mean, when I was in Washington, besides it's freezing. As long as you folks said the next step is to do something big to shore up support for the banking system and I ask someone but why not just nationalize them since that is what we're doing any way? Taxpayers are putting in it and one of - you know, you may not be that far off.

O'NEILL: I tell you what, I would do something a lot bigger than that. I would try and find a CEO to come on your show for half an hour and dissect their balance sheet for the American public to show that they really know what is in it and they can attest to its underlying values. So that if I was running a big bank and I have $200 billion worth of commercial loans that have been outstanding five years and I could say that these are all performing. I could say here is 200 billion, those are all performing. Here's another 100 billion and there are some late payments in this segment and so we have to mark those down.

CAVUTO: Your argument is that their books don't look nearly as bad as we've been led to believe. We got this Draconian end of the world description on the way we look at those books is unrealistic.

O'NEILL: My argument is this, if we don't tell the truth and make it clear that we know for certain what are a good assets it leaves the question, are any of the assets good? And that is why yesterday we had a 25, 30 percent sell-off in most of the financial institutions -

TABACCO: Today is a mere snapshot of what will happen.

HOWARD ROSENCRANS, FOX BUSINESS ANALYST: I'm not going to bet against Apple. The marketing is brilliant. I haven't heard any of these things John has heard that had all the negative commentary associated with the maps. It is an amazing company. All that said, you're talking about 10 billion dollars in an individual quarter in an economy that continues to deteriorate at the high end.

CAVUTO: That was an impressive. They sold very well in a tough environment.

TABACCO: Think about how much stimulus money we gave out last year to buy stuff like iPhones. Is that going to keep going?

CAVUTO: We could have bought other places.

TABACCO: There was great marketing, no doubt. But you haven't heard that the iPhones are freezing up and the batteries stink? You haven't heard that?

ROSENCRANS: At the margin.

(CROSS TALK)

TABACCO: I hear a lot of guys switching back.

TRACY BYRNES, FOX BUSINESS ANALYST: I think what they have done is genius, because they were selling the Mac. The Mac was their bread and butter for a while. That slowed. They got the Phone. Sales were up 88 percent, which is amazing. Now that the you got the iPhone, you are going to want to buy a Mac. People are going to want to integrate the whole thing.

CAVUTO: You see that continuing.

BYRNES: I totally seeing it continuing. But I don't see this Steve Jobs health thing going away.

CAVUTO: All right, Jonathan Hoenig, back to Steve Jobs and whether that is going to have a pall over the company? People are going to start thinking, you know, he is the guy who makes all this possible, what happens?

JONATHAN HOENIG, FOX BUSINESS ANALYST: Neil, the stock has been hurt and has been hurt very sharply even when people thought Steve Jobs's health was a lot better. Even with today's pop up after-hours, up about eight percent, stock is still near a 52-week low.

CAVUTO: It is around 90, right? It's highest was 185, something like that?

HOENIG: Right. And basically this is a market performer now. It is 13 percent of the Nasdaq 100. Until that next technology that Tracy alluded to --

CAVUTO: Really?

HOENIG: It is the major tech stock. It really is a cult stock, Neil. Until they get that new technology out there that inspires people to line up outside the Apple stores all over America, I don't think it is going to be a place you make any money.

CAVUTO: All right, I was way wrong on that Apple quote. I'm sorry. The chart was accurate. I wasn't. John, at 82 or something, how low does this thing go then?

TABACCO: Maybe me and Howard should do a double or nothing on our Lehman bet. I would say you see 60 before 120.

ROSENCRANS: I'm in your camp, John. I'm embarrassed because of the macro picture associated with it. I don't see them --

CAVUTO: Do you guys find something weird going on here? Apple has a good report. IBM optimistic looking into the next fiscal year. These are some big tech heavyweights that are saying, you know, the water is just fine.

ROSENCRANS: Apple came out and they made commentary on the immediate quarter. They don't put it out any further than that. They're always providing cautious commentary. However, they did suggest a fairly powerful quarter.

IBM, on the other hand, when you're talking about 29 billion dollars in the quarter, that does make a hell of a statement. It suggests -- because IBM can not be just an IBM story. It has to be a decent commentary. Somehow they are seeing --

BYRNES: If you look at the numbers, Neil, a lot of it was in their servicing. What that means is people in IBM's case are keeping their computers, and having things serviced to make them last longer. Nobody wants to go out and buy things. They keep putting out products, Apple. I keep buying them for my kids. Stock will save up.

TABACCO: So people are servicing their IBMs, but they are going to run out and buy a Mac because they love their iPhone. That is contrary.

BYRNES: It is not. This was the --

CAVUTO: Guys, we have to pay our bills here. We're not right now. So mixed messages from the markets to President Obama. But the president was pretty clear in what he wanted to tell Wall Street today. We'll explain.

CAVUTO: All right. Down about 300 points on inauguration day. Up about 300 points on his first full in office. Mixed messages from the street to its young president. But a clear message to Wall Street from the president. He is freezing salaries of any White House staff making over 100,000 dollars a year. That is about what Hoenig makes in an hour.

So 100,000, is that the new rich? Jonathan?

HOENIG: Well, for Obama, Neil, that line is kind of changed for quite a long time, right? It was 250. Then it went down to 200.

CAVUTO: I'll tell you something, Jonathan, when he first started campaigning a couple years ago, a millionaire was rich. You earn a million dollars -- throughout the campaign, it went down and down.

HOENIG: It keeps going lower. Listen, every company in America, Neil, is freezing salaries. So on some level, I'm glad to see him taking some responsibility for spending in Washington. What worries me more though is the control he is likely to exert over private sector about what they pay their CEOs and their executives, not to mention the hundreds of billions of dollars that he's going to be shuffling out the door to all his pet projects.

CAVUTO: I think Jonathan hit on a brilliant point. I think what is going on here -- you know, they always have the gap between the rich and the poor, Tracy, I think rather than bring the bottom up, let's whack the top down?

BYRNES: If you go through even the tax proposals, not one of them, not anything applies to anybody who makes over 200,000. And actually, it is at 150,000 where they start to phase out. He is not giving anything to the people at the top. And as you're saying, we even hear Pelosi saying she wants to raise taxes on the top. So yes, he is going to try to bring us all down into this happy minimum.

CAVUTO: Now I have a new Machiavellian theory on that. That was a trial balloon for the administration to stick it to the rich sooner. What do you think, John?

TABACCO: I say let the social engineering begin. This is the first in one of many moves that you'll see. A hundred thousand, that is all you can make. Now we can hire a lot more 20, 30, 40 thousand dollar employees.

CAVUTO: Is that the message the government sends, that all of a sudden you're saying, 100,000 sounds like a lot to us. Do you think, Howard, it is telling private sector, if you're cutting, go to that crowd?

ROSENCRANS: Listen, it sending a nice, quote, message. At end of the day, though, it is pretty important to want to attract the best people to work in this profession. To make a commentary on what people are going to get paid in the private sector or to it in government, to send the message that, it is --

CAVUTO: I just found out the other day what other anchors here are being paid. Ticks me off royally. Jonathan Hoenig, I'm looking at that, and I'm just saying, this could be the opening salvo to social engineering. Or am I over-dramatizing it?

HOENIG: Neil, it absolutely is. Now, of course, the government is a major shareholder throughout the entire financial world, in Citibank, in Bank of America. Believe me, the Barney Franks, the Chris Dodds, and yes, President Obama are going to make a big deal about what those on the top, even some of those in the middle are making in terms of salary at the end of the day.

BYRNES: Those guys in D.C. never made a lot of money to begin with. They all make between 100 and 200 to begin with. He's not making a --

CAVUTO: How long are they going to be frozen?

TABACCO: Who knows? Probably for a while. Most government workers I know get paid, like you said, between 100 and 200. But they work like 20 hours a day, these guys, already.

CAVUTO: A lot of them do.

TABACCO: You can't make more than 100 grand. What kind of opportunity are you creating for these people to work as hard as you're working now or harder, because we're in tough times.

BYRNES: They're doing it for the good of the people.

CAVUTO: I think he is sending a message, we're pulling our belts in.

TABACCO: People that should be worried are the guys like Robert Kennedy. We need innovation to go green and we don't have the money to get innovation.

CAVUTO: When we come back, he let his mother-in-law move into the White House, got the Jonas Brothers to perform for his kids in the White House, and endured two straight hours of watching a parade outside the White House. Policy aside, if that isn't devotion, I don't know what is.

CAVUTO: Can I ask you something? Do you like parades? I got into a lot of trouble last night when I said I'm not a big fan of them myself. Nothing personal. But they just kind of go on and on and on. I got more than a few marching band coordinators sick. One of them e-mailed me to say "had he been there, he would have heaved a baton at my skull." Said, "I should be more like President and Mrs. Obama. Not only do they love a parade, they're among the first few couples, at least that I have ever seen, never to take their eyes off it. Never."

I saw it for myself. They were just about the last ones standing in that White House reviewing stand. I'm not kidding. Because I was across the street.

Anyway, look at this, when the parade started, all those coveted seats in the glass enclosed stand were taken, even the cheap seats out in the freezing cold. Then only minutes into the parade, they all start scattering like me at a health food store. You've got cabinet secretaries and social secretaries and pretty much all the secretaries, then even the dude who was serving drinks.

Soon even Sasha and Malia were out of there. The mother-in-law too. By the parade's wee end, barely a wee soul in that stand, save the cheering and waving and very happy Barack and Michelle Obama.

I didn't once see them take a break or once not acknowledge every marcher and twirler and flipper and singer and trumpeter, not a one. Sure, you could say it was in their honor; they had to stay. Actually, they didn't. They had inaugurals balls to go to, and since everything was running late, really, really late, this marching madness was cutting into what was supposed to be two hours of quiet quality time in their new home.

No matter. If the band played on, they stayed on. As my headache from all the noise just went on and on. I kept asking, surely they can't take two hours of this without a break? They just smiled and waved, as if to say, actually, yes, we can. Republicans be warned, if you think you can roll these guys, think again. They have endured more than you going on and on. They've endured the ultimate, parades that go on and on, even longer. And they even looked happy doing it.

It's not right. Good night.

urn:contentItem:5KR6-6F91-DY0W-44XY-00000-00White House Puts Ceiling on Government Salaries2009-01-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:46:07ZLexisNexisWhite House Puts Ceiling on Government SalariesWalthamFULL TEXT

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM GEITHNER, TREASURY SECRETARY NOMINEE: These were careless mistakes. They were avoidable mistakes but they were unintentional.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN HOST: (Inaudible), Tim but fear not, you are in, Tim. Tim Geithner survives the hearing about his taxes but not enough about how he plans to spend our taxes. Tonight the man who had the job Tim wants on the screw ups should make sure he does not repeat if he wants to keep that job. Then Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. seeing red over those who question all the green going green. And they say life is a parade but does that mean we have to do what the president does and stick out through the whole darn thing? We are ready to march, now.

CAVUTO: Tim Geithner gets a grilling on the taxes he didn't pay but not nearly so much on his role in failed financial rescue in which he - well all of us continue to pay. Welcome, I am Neil Cavuto. And here's the deal. Tim Geithner will be Treasury Secretary of the United States not because charges of sloppy bookkeeping aren't serious but because this financial crisis is even more serious. Yet at his Senate confirmation hearing today Mr. Geithner got more of a pummeling on his books than how he has helped handle the nation's books. He wasn't in charge of those books, mind you, but the very least he was a co-author, a co-signee if you will.

Our financial loans didn't loan and didn't rescue at bailouts that they themselves had to be bailed out. I'd like to hear more on how we botch those numbers than buttoning(ph) his own numbers. Some senators would carp about TARP but you asked Mr. Geithner how he would avoid another lark with TARP. And all because fear grips us and gosh Tim knows this stuff. He is smart. He is seasoned and he is ready just like Robert McMamara who led us into Vietnam and couldn't get us out. And Donald Rumsfeld who led us into Iraq without a plant o get us out.

So I'm trying to figure out this obsession with brainiacs. Take nothing away from how smart they are but how dumb maybe we are, too intimidated to think, maybe they aren't so smart especially when we can all clearly see the fall out of the financial rescue and assess for what it's been - dumb so far.

My next guest was asking these very question on TARP before it became a trap. In fact, George Bush's first Treasury Secretary had very serious questions and reservations about the rescue concocted by George Bush's last Treasury Secretary. Paul O'Neill joins me now. Well, good to have you.

PAUL O'NEILL, FMR. TREASURY SECRETARY: Thank you.

CAVUTO: First on Geithner, should he get it?

O'NEILL: He's going to get in.

CAVUTO: Should he?

O'NEILL: I think on balance, yes.

CAVUTO: Normally these issues - forgetting to pay your taxes and all would doom any other nominee in any other time or at least drag it out but not now because of the crisis, I guess. Should they?

O'NEILL: You know, I think as I understand the circumstances is there is to pay at some of thousands of dollars of taxes. I think as he said it is unfortunate and he wishes he had avoided but on balance I think he had to go ahead and get the job.

CAVUTO: OK. Now, your argument has always been it's the big picture and I will hit the tax saying one more time with you. Part of the big picture is knowing what you run. And part of what you run is the IRS and the folks who make the tax rules.

You don't know all the rules, you know, I don't think even they do. But it still maybe they don't but still if they send a message that he does not.

O'NEILL: Well, I don't know. Here is a question for you. There are 10,000 pages in the tax code, do you think there's any human being that understand the whole tax code? I don't. In the time I was secretary -

CAVUTO: The tax is -

O'NEILL: Well, Neil, I will give you an example. Do you know, that if you have an employee yourself, who cleans your house and it's against the law for you to give them a gift. Did you know, that? You probably thought you could give $10,000 a year to anyone without reporting it to the gift tax threshold. If not true, if you give your housekeeper a Christmas gift even if it's in goods, but particularly if it's in cash, say $10,000, you have to report it as wages paid and paid the withholding taxes on it.

(CROSSTALK)

O'NEILL: I'm giving you a specific thing. I'm telling you there are 10,000 pages.

CAVUTO: Not a big deal, move on, is what you are saying?

I would be ripped more for the handling of his role in the TARP funds that you are very critical about early on because what you saw what happened indeed has happened. So now we're going to release the other hundred 350 billion, the House is improving all these conditions, with strict provisos but they're going to screw up again.

O'NEILL: You know, when I was here with you before I told you that I thought that it was a very big mistake for the federal government to assume preferred equity positions in financial institutions. Because I greatly fear the conversation that we heard yesterday about the Royal Bank of Scotland being nationalized by the U.K. government and with the -

CAVUTO: That is a preview of coming attractions -

O'NEILL: With the flow through into the conversation here in the U.S that the federal government would have to nationalize the bank which is the worst possible idea.

CAVUTO: Well, let me ask you, a couple of months - when did I have you last time? I'm just trying to remember this because we were racing at the time with all rescues going on and at that time when they nixed the Lehman Brothers rescue. Here's what you had to say about that. Let's get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: What if something happens with Lehman? What if something happens with Lehman? You think -

O'NEILL: I'd let them go.

CAVUTO: Really?

O'NEILL: Yes. Because I think the rest of the system is sufficiently well insulated if Lehman goes down it is a consequence for the shareholders, employer and leadership but that is OK with me.

CAVUTO: You draw the line here.

O'NEILL: Yes, I think you draw the line here.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CAVUTO: Now all the Monday morning quarterback are all saying you should not have done that, not you, but Lehman should have been rescued.

O'NEILL: You know, I haven't changed my mind. If you listen carefully with what I said we should let the shareholders go to zero.

CAVUTO: Right.

O'NEILL: I didn't intend by that that we should throw the whole financial system into chaos and I think -

CAVUTO: That's what happens this Monday morning, they were saying because that is what we did. We let them go not appreciating the fact that it would let the financial system go.

O'NEILL: Yes. I think we need to be concerned. We need to worry. We need to intervene in a way that the financial system doesn't collapse because of absolute uncertainty about the counter party relationships and all of that. But it seems perfectly appropriate to me for people who are running private enterprises to if they do things that are substantially bad for them to be wiped out.

CAVUTO: We're going quite the opposite way now, right. I mean, when I was in Washington, besides it's freezing. As long as you folks said the next step is to do something big to shore up support for the banking system and I ask someone but why not just nationalize them since that is what we're doing any way? Taxpayers are putting in it and one of - you know, you may not be that far off.

O'NEILL: I tell you what, I would do something a lot bigger than that. I would try and find a CEO to come on your show for half an hour and dissect their balance sheet for the American public to show that they really know what is in it and they can attest to its underlying values. So that if I was running a big bank and I have $200 billion worth of commercial loans that have been outstanding five years and I could say that these are all performing. I could say here is 200 billion, those are all performing. Here's another 100 billion and there are some late payments in this segment and so we have to mark those down.

CAVUTO: Your argument is that their books don't look nearly as bad as we've been led to believe. We got this Draconian end of the world description on the way we look at those books is unrealistic.

O'NEILL: My argument is this, if we don't tell the truth and make it clear that we know for certain what are a good assets it leaves the question, are any of the assets good? And that is why yesterday we had a 25, 30 percent sell-off in most of the financial institutions -

CAVUTO: We're going to keep seeing that. They bounced back today but this is just a roller-coaster.

O'NEILL: You know what, I think, I'm sorry (inaudible). I love having you on but I do want to get to this. Would you rescue or shore up Citigroup, Bank of America because they got almost $100 million of taxpayer money and they're still hurting puppies? Would you give them more?

O'NEILL: First of all, I would convert - any money that's been put into these institutions on a preferred stock basis I would replace it with federal 20-year loans with 200 basis points interest over the federal borrowing rate and then say to the regulators counted this as permanent capital. And then I would get if they asked the auto companies to do, I would get city, and JP Morgan and Bank of America to come in individually and dissect their portfolio and to the degree that they have, maybe 20 percent of their portfolio that they can't really value, that ought to be an open -

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: What about central repository? I call it a suppository for sick banks and their toxic assets.

O'NEILL: Why do we want to do that? We ought to solve them on their own bottom.

CAVUTO: I'm telling you the Obama folks are seriously considering.

O'NEILL: I understand they are.

CAVUTO: And you think it's a stupid idea.

O'NEILL: I didn't say stupid but I think but I think -

CAVUTO: Is there a better way?

O'NEILL: I think there's a better way, Neil.

CAVUTO: Silly, clownish and bureaucratically the most inept thing you've ever heard in your life?

O'NEILL: I don't think it's the best idea. I think solving the individual financial institutions on their own bottom by having absolute clarity about what we know for sure. I give you an example. Right now, they all report the late pays and the (inaudible) on credit card every month. They ought to be able to do the same thing about all the loans that are on their books and if they can't do that, maybe you'll tell me they can't do it and I'll say we are really in trouble.

CAVUTO: We're really in trouble. That's what I'm saying. I'm saying they can't.

O'NEILL: I don't think we need to be in that trouble. I think we need somebody who will stand up and tell the truth.

CAVUTO: All right. As you are standing telling the truth, speaking your mind. What would happen to you?

O'NEILL: Well, I tell you what. Sometimes, it's OK to get fired if you're telling the truth.

CAVUTO: All right. Well I will dodge that at all cost. Well, thank you very much, very good seeing you. The former, fine treasury secretary of this United States, Paul O'Neill.

When we come back Hillary Clinton is going to state and who is going to fill her seat. Does Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. know. What would you like to know? We'll find out next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: All right. As expected a bit of a battle, a back and forth, a bit of a drama that Hillary Clinton is going to be the next Secretary of State. The Senate overwhelmingly approving that choice. Reaction from Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. on her appointment because remember his cousin Caroline could fill Hillary Clinton's Senate shoes.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERT F. KENNEDY JR.: I think Obama has himself as a good secretary of state. You saw her at the confirmation. She was prepared. She's smart. She is quick. She is thoughtful. And she as we know and you know that she's diplomatic personally. So I think - I don't think he could have gotten a better choice.

CAVUTO: Do you think this will get about eventually closing it (inaudible) she had one view on this subject, Robert, against you know, against Gitmo but not against closing it. I think that was the end campaign position and now the president, her boss is -

KENNEDY: She's going to do what her boss wants to do. And I think in the long run, I saw the piece you had on before this about some of the technical problems that's going to cause. You know, Neil, I travel all over the world and it has given this country such a black eye that -- that it really is a public relations catastrophe for us and the quicker we close it, the better.

CAVUTO: Al these countries criticize us. It's weird. And they don't want the prisoners either.

KENNEDY: It's not only the countries, it's the people. It's just what it has come to symbolize that this is the way Americans torture people. And that's what it will always symbolize because we crossed the line that we'd never crossed in our history before, you know.

CAVUTO: Someone crossed the line with us, right?

KENNEDY: After World War II, we executed Japanese officers for water boarding Americans. So this is a place we never torture people. George Washington during the revolution refused to torture British soldiers even though they were torturing us. Our soldiers are right here New York Harbor.

Abraham Lincoln actually when he was confronted with the idea of torturing people, he was so horrified that he created a commission that developed humane standards for fair treatment of prisoners.

CAVUTO: So bottomline -

KENNEDY: -- Later the Geneva convention.

CAVUTO: Understood. But you don't think this is a divisive issue between secretary of state?

KENNEDY: I think, absolutely that everybody I think will understand. Anybody who has to deal with foreign government's and foreign populations can understand that this has got to go.

CAVUTO: Understood. Well (inaudible). Your cousin, Caroline, the front runner for that supposed Senate seat that's opening up. What do you think of that?

KENNEDY: I hope she gets it. There's an electorate of one. So it's all up to David Paterson.

CAVUTO: What about the criticism that she got?

KENNEDY: We're in New York, Neil. Everybody gets criticized in New York.

CAVUTO: Why not you?

KENNEDY: I couldn't do it. As we discussed before I have six kids and that is a lot of mouths to feed. They all want to eat and they all want to go to school.

CAVUTO: You are a Kennedy you have money coming out of the yin yang. No?

KENNEDY: Well, I've always have to make my own money.

CAVUTO: All right. Let's talk a little bit about the environmental stuff. It's the reason why I got you in the beginning. You are very gracious to take these other questions. The environmental push, the administration is making it clear that while it is trying to free salaries for those members in the administration 100 grand or more, it is still very much on track to spend a lot of green going green. Should it?

KENNEDY: Yes. You know, if we need an industry that's going to bring us out of this depression. The quickest way that we can restore the economy in this country is to get off of foreign oil but two months ago we were spending $700 billion a year. We are borrowing $1 billion a day from countries that don't like us.

CAVUTO: How do you know that going green will make the world right?

KENNEDY: That will make the world what?

CAVUTO: Right. With all of this strategy or technology?

KENNEDY: If we get off of foreign oil people, everybody say OK we gave 700 billion to Citibank. It's going to take generations to pay it back. It's not going to take generations. It's going to take one year without foreign oil. We pay the whole thing back. It's going to generate huge dividends for our economy.

CAVUTO: But what if we made a hunch on an investment that what essentially the government is doing and it turns out to be a bad bet?

KENNEDY: It's not a investment bet. It is creating an infrastructure that will allow the free market economy to function in the lowest cost producers of energy to get into the marketplace. They can't do that now, Neil.

CAVUTO: But the free-market looks at it and says it is not our cup of tea. What are we going to do?

KENNEDY: The marketplace is already out there. People are clamoring to hook up. Look at T. Boone Pickens. You know, I'm involved with green tech firms like Vantage Point. They are clamoring to build wind and solar. The problem is we don't have a grid that can carry that energy, that can transfer the electrons. What we need to do is create a national grid that is smart grid that can deploy, store and deploy energy, it will cost $150 billion to do that.

Once you do that, we have free energy in this country forever. We never have to go over to Saudi Arabia. We don't have to get 4.5 trillion dollar wars. We don't have to spend $100 billion per year protecting pipelines.

CAVUTO: you think that this commitment to go green is going to wipe our dependence on oil?

KENNEDY: Oh yes, of course, it is.

CAVUTO: How soon?

KENNEDY: As soon as we wanted to. Israel is doing it in three years. If Israel can do it. We can do it too. All we have to do. Listen, in 1979, we had no - we built and we bought days to build the Arpanet(ph), an internet grid essentially.

The year later, 1980, there were fewer than 500 PCs in this country and IBM said it was a dead-end technology. But because we built the marketplace, the grid where everybody could hook up. Everybody in this country has PCs today and the world has been transformed. All we need to do is build a national grid that can reach the big wind there, the midwest of this country is the Saudi Arabia of when we have the most wind just in North Dakota, Montana and Texas to provide all the energy needed -

CAVUTO: Just in D.C.

Soon even Sasha and Malia were out of there. The mother-in-law too. By the parade's wee end, barely a wee soul in that stand, save the cheering and waving and very happy Barack and Michelle Obama.

I didn't once see them take a break or once not acknowledge every marcher and twirler and flipper and singer and trumpeter, not a one. Sure, you could say it was in their honor; they had to stay. Actually, they didn't. They had inaugurals balls to go to, and since everything was running late, really, really late, this marching madness was cutting into what was supposed to be two hours of quiet quality time in their new home.

No matter. If the band played on, they stayed on. As my headache from all the noise just went on and on. I kept asking, surely they can't take two hours of this without a break? They just smiled and waved, as if to say, actually, yes, we can. Republicans be warned, if you think you can roll these guys, think again. They have endured more than you going on and on. They've endured the ultimate, parades that go on and on, even longer. And they even looked happy doing it.

It's not right. Good night.

END
