urn:contentItem:5XGW-0BN1-JBYT-H410-00000-00Whoop, the sports tech and analytics company that makes discreet wearables, raises $55M2019-11-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:46:07ZLexisNexisWhoop, the sports tech and analytics company that makes discreet wearables, raises $55MNew Delhi, 2019-11-13 16:13:58

November 13 -- On the heels of Google buying Fitbit for $2.1 billion, another player in wearables and health technology has picked up a big round of growth funding to continue expanding its business. Whoop, which makes a sensor-equipped (and screen-free) strap that continuously tracks your activities 24/7 and then provides a multitude of performance metrics and other data based on that activity, has closed a round of $55 million, a Series D that it will use to continue expanding its business into a wider range of wearables and analytics that can be gathered around them.


Today the devices measure things like how much strain a workout is causing you, how you are recovering afterwards, your sleep, whether training is having the desired effect, whether you are working at a level that will be less likely to cause injury and how you are likely to perform. Looking ahead, the plan is to bring the sensors into more places than just the strap it currently makes. "You'll see Whoop over time worn throughout your body," CEO Will Ahmed said. "The tech can live in other areas of the body, people will not even know you are wearing a sensor. We like the idea of tech being invisible while still being there."
The funding brings the total to more than $100 million for the Boston-based company, and while Ahmed, who originally incubated the startup at Harvard with co-founders John Capodilupo and Aurelian Nicolae, said the valuation was not being disclosed, he did describe it as "healthy" - which I guess is appropriate for a health-tech company.
For some context, PitchBook notes that its last round of $25 million, in 2018, was at $125 million, post-money. That would mean a minimum of $180 million here, although the "healthy" implies it is actually higher. (We'll continue to dig around and will update the number if we learn more.)
Whoop doesn't disclose how many users it has currently, or anything about its financials, but its investor list is a good measure of the traction that Whoop has had to date, as a company pitching its product not just to the mass market, but to an elite group of sports people - who in turn are not just major athletes, but, in this day and age, major influencers when it comes to purchasing power.
This latest round was led by Foundry Group - coincidentally also an investor in Fitbit - with participation from Two Sigma Ventures, Accomplice, Thursday Ventures, Promus Ventures and Silicon Valley Bank. Individual investors included David Stern, the former NBA Commissioner; Ed Baker, former VP of product and growth at Uber, and former head of International Growth at Facebook; Marc Randolph, co-founder and first CEO of Netflix; and Nicholas Negroponte, MIT Media Lab.
Previous backers of the company include the Durant Company, the National Football League Players Association, Twitter chief executive Jack Dorsey, Los Angeles Chargers offensive tackle Russell Okung and Mike Novogratz, the chief executive of Galaxy Digital.
One notable shift Whoop has seen in the last year is that it has dropped the price of its wearable from an eye-watering $500 down to free. Instead, it bundles the strap into a wider membership program that you do pay for, starting at $30/month and decreasing, depending on what you would like to measure and use the data for (specifically, pricing is six months of data for $30/month; 12 months for $24/month; or 18 months for $18/month).
Offering its devices for free is just one of the ways that Whoop diverges from the usual wearables story.
At a time when wearables have become part of the gadget pantheon, equipped with screens and acting as little computers in their own right, Whoop has taken a very different turn, opting to build a device that looks nothing like a piece of electronics, even if behind the scenes it's using just as much AI and other powerful technology to crunch the data that its five sensors are continuously collecting.
"The dirty secret with wearables is that the more features you try to pack in to them, the less effective they are," Ahmed said. "We have been deliberate about what we want our tech to do. We think about the context of what will make the experience better, and if it doesn't we're not doing it."
He gave me a flat "no comment" on the subject of whether Whoop had ever been approached for acquisition, but it's notable to watch what has been happening around big tech. Apple has been seeing sales growth of its Watch outpace its other iconic products. Amazon is building a massive health services business that will likely also have a hardware component. And Google's acquisition of Fitbit (if it clears all regulatory and other hurdles) is a big sign of how the company also sees this area as one where it will want to have a seat at the table.
"Google buying Fitbit is a sign that health data will be a big piece of the future for tech companies," Ahmed said, pointing out that the company's lack of growth in device sales is a strong sign that Google bought it largely for its data capabilities. "It puts a big value on data and what it's done there and suggests Google will use the data to create health products."

urn:contentItem:5Y8K-NHK1-JCBW-N4P7-00000-00Who really cares about privacy on the internet?;People claim to be worried about giving away personal data, but their behaviour suggests otherwise,2020-02-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:46:07ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Who really cares about privacy on the internet?People claim to be worried about giving away personal data, but their behaviour suggests otherwise,Eilis O'Hanlon

N O one likes banks, not even bankers probably, so there was no shortage of people eager to pile in on Barclays after it introduced a monitoring system on company computers in the city of London to check how much time its employees actually spend working.

The electronic spies have now been switched off following a ferocious backlash - or "colleague feedback", as Barclays put it rather more euphemistically. Now they're insisting it was just a trial programme, which is, of course, what any public relations adviser would tell a big company found to have been behaving with the sensitivity of a Victorian workhouse owner to say, whether it was true or not.

Privacy campaign group Big Brother Watch condemned the use of such tracking software as "creepy", and who could possibly argue with that? Workers said they couldn't even go to the toilet without being logged as away from their desks, and potentially asked to explain themselves. It's good to be reminded that individuals have some rights, even in this anxious age of job insecurity.

But there's still something a bit hollow at the sight of so many people getting their knickers in a twist because their boss is spying on them.

Everything's spying on everyone these days, including the technology which these same people willingly use in their free time. We all suspect our phones are listening in, however much it is denied.

How often have you been at home, idly chatting about needing to pick up shampoo, or biscuits, or whatever, and, the next time you switch on your phone, there are ads for the very same products? It's called surveillance capitalism.

One woman recently noticed that she'd started getting ads for pregnancy products and baby clothing, even though she wasn't having a baby. It turned out that she'd stopped using her "period tracker" app and it, and the third parties to which the makers of said app had been selling on data, assumed she was therefore with child.

Every song you ask Alexa to play on the Amazon Echo Dot, every video you watch on YouTube, gets fed through some unique algorithm, or however the heck this stuff works - because that's another factor, we don't really know how all this fits together, we just leave it to the billionaires and boffins in Silicon Valley to do their thing, and hope for the best - and soon your phone or tablet knows you better than you know yourself. We're spied on all the time. We've just chosen not to care.

It's like when people are shown where sausages come from. RTE presenter Philip Boucher-Hayes actually made some on The Late, Late Show a few years ago while plugging his health show What Are You Eating? Pig's rectums. Fat. Enough salt to empty a Siberian salt mine. Sodium tripolyphosphate - a common ingredient in detergent. It would be easier to list what didn't go in the sausages.

The audience at home was "disgusted", the headlines de-clared. The audience in the studio, who'd been treated to some cocktail sausages during that particular segment, even more so. People across the land pledged never to eat processed sausages again.

A couple of weeks later, everyone was tucking into a Full Irish, as if they'd never known the truth of what they were putting in their mouths.

"Humankind cannot bear very much reality," as the poet TS Eliot once noted.

It's the same with technology. Those little devices we all carry around are designed to reward the brain with a constant diet of little treats so that it forgets what would bring it pain to remember, and recalls only the pleasure.

Yes, our phones spy on us, but they also let us watch Netflix on the bus to and from work, or ping repeatedly to notify us that someone else has liked that picture of our children on Facebook.

That's another contradiction, of course. The people who complain most loudly about online privacy are often the same ones who put their entire lives on the internet, often dragging in a host of family, friends and randomers who never consented to their faces appearing online.

A startup company in the US recently started selling software to police departments which claimed to be able to identify people from photographs. Such a tool is obviously of use to police looking to track down criminals, but it transpired that the database in the software was compiled by pulling images from "open web" sources such as Google, Facebook and Twitter without the owners' permission.

The company was subsequently served with cease and desist letters, but insists that it uses only publicly available data.

Most people when asked say they're comfortable with using facial recognition software to unlock their own phones, but, once your face becomes just another piece of data, is it still your own? Everything can be boiled down to usable nuggets of information which can then be sold on. Everybody knows this is how the internet works, but we're like celebrities, who say they want privacy but then demand attention when they have some new product to sell or message to pass on.

That we don't really understand the technology makes it harder to know what we're agreeing to when we sign up to a new service or tick those pop-up boxes which appear on never-before-visited websites.

A growing number claim to read the terms and conditions of the apps they download, but it's still far from being a majority. Most wouldn't understand the small print even if they did. Vaguely we're aware that it has something to do with GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation), but, beyond that, it's as fathomable to the average person as sorcery.

We just want to surf the internet, not study for a degree in computer science, and lawmakers are no more clued in to what's going on.

Even the candidates running in the US Democratic primary race for the right to challenge Donald Trump for the presidency in November appear baffled by technology.

Elizabeth Warren wants the CEOs of big companies to go to jail if they breach the privacy of a certain number of users. Bernie Sanders also says they should be prosecuted.

Billionaire Michael Bloomberg wants the US to adopt a GDPR system similar to that pioneered by the EU.

Other than that, gaps in the conversation are filled with the sound of crickets, and it was the same in the election here. Good luck finding any policies on online privacy from the major parties' manifestos.

Many have called for the big tech companies to be broken up or regulated, but that wouldn't solve the real problem, which is that surveillance is built into every aspect of the online world. That's how they make money. Lots of it.

The real irony is that the reason technology needs to spy on us at work, in the way that got Barclays Bank into trouble this week, is because technology also interferes with our ability to concentrate for sustained periods, unless it's on a new Netflix series.

The campaign group Privacy International says that "people are entitled to some fundamental rights even if they are at work", but do bosses not also have a right to be peeved if they're paying staff for a day's work and a goodly proportion of those hours is spent scrolling through each other's social media feeds? The tracking systems may even be doing us all a favour in the long run by keeping us away from time-wasting distractions. As Prof Neil Postman put it in his 1980s book about how television was dumbing down public discourse, we may well be "amusing ourselves to death".

The boss only demands your time. Technology colonises our very souls.

'Everything

can be boiled

urn:contentItem:5S6H-T7B1-JBVM-Y3NG-00000-00Who really cares what tech firms are up to?2018-04-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:46:07ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 32Who really cares what tech firms are up to?Matthew Lynn

They are harvesting too much data, closing down competition, distorting markets, destroying jobs, bankrupting governments by avoiding taxes, and undermining democracy by allowing voters to be manipulated by foreign www.powers.No one has quite said Amazon or Facebook burn babies for office fuel but just about every other charge you can think of has been thrown at them. A consensus is fast emerging that Big Tech is a Big Problem - and that it will have to be regulated more closely, and some of the biggest internet companies may even have to be broken up.

But hold on. There is very little sign the customers mind about any of this. While the arguments over more and more draconian regulation become more intense, the tech giants keep reporting better and better results.

They are signing up vast quantities of new people and pushing into new industries. In fact, we risk destroying the most dynamic and innovative part of the global economy with a largely synthetic hysteria over their growing power. The European Union is leading the way with campaigns for tighter controls over the huge American companies that dominate the internet.

Next month, tough new laws on data privacy come into force. A turnover tax is planned to capture more of their profits. Massive fines running into billions have been imposed for restricting competition, with more on the way. There has even been talk of breaking up Google.

While the EU is making the running, the United States and the rest of the world are not far behind. President Trump has been leading an assault on Amazon, and there has been talk of turning both it and Google into regulated utilities as the only way of curbing their power.

Indeed, the International Monetary Fund chief Christine Lagarde said this month the IMF was looking at ways of controlling their power.

There are legitimate concerns. Google dominates internet search, and increasingly advertising as well.

Amazon dominates online retailing, and Facebook owns the social media industry. In many areas, they are virtually monopolies - and they always need to be carefully controlled.

And yet, if they were quite as bad as some politicians and campaigners think they are, you might imagine customers would be turning away from them. If so, there is very little evidence of it. In fact, the results have been better than ever.

This week, Amazon unveiled doubled first-quarter profits. It now has more than 100m Prime subscribers, despite a price rise, and sales across the company are now an extraordinary $550m (£400m) a day. Google easily beat expectations with its results, adding another 20pc to its already huge profits. Likewise, Facebook reported record results. And Netflix this month reported booming subscriptions despite a price rise some critics thought might be a step too far.

It is not as if any of them are selling essential services like food or clothing. We'd all get by fine without Facebook and if we really believed Amazon was destroying the world, there are still plenty of other places to buy a book, a new router, or a Lego activity set for the kids. They are growing so fast because we are in love with the products, and because the value and service they offer, and the levels of innovation, remain fantastic.

The hysterical clamour for regulation looks manufactured by a small political elite, and often, as in the case of the EU or IMF, by officials and regulators who haven't been elected. In many cases, it may well be driven by lobbying from old economy rivals.

To take one example, the only way for traditional broadcasters to compete against Netflix now might well be to regulate them out of existence. There is a risk here, and a big one. We could do huge damage to the most dynamic part of the global economy by taxing, regulating or breaking up the tech giants now. These are all companies that are still investing on a gargantuan scale. Alphabet, Google's parent, now spends $16bn a year on research. Amazon spent $22bn.

The top five companies for R&D spending in the US last year were all in tech, throwing $76bn between them at developing new products. There is still a huge amount of innovation ahead, from financial services, to cars, to artificial intelligence, robotics and space. We can tax and regulate that away if we want to. But it would be a huge waste to lose all of those products, and the jobs and wealth they will create, because of issues most of us probably don't really care about.
